00034 // This header file defines the public API for death tests.  It is
00035 // #included by gtest.h so a user doesn't need to include this
00036 // directly.
00037 
00038 #ifndef GTEST_INCLUDE_GTEST_GTEST_DEATH_TEST_H_
00039 #define GTEST_INCLUDE_GTEST_GTEST_DEATH_TEST_H_
00040 
00041 #include <gtest/internal/gtest-death-test-internal.h>
00042 
00043 namespace testing {
00044 
00045 // This flag controls the style of death tests.  Valid values are "threadsafe",
00046 // meaning that the death test child process will re-execute the test binary
00047 // from the start, running only a single death test, or "fast",
00048 // meaning that the child process will execute the test logic immediately
00049 // after forking.
00050 GTEST_DECLARE_string_(death_test_style);
00051 
00052 #ifdef GTEST_HAS_DEATH_TEST
00053 
00054 // The following macros are useful for writing death tests.
00055 
00056 // Here's what happens when an ASSERT_DEATH* or EXPECT_DEATH* is
00057 // executed:
00058 //
00059 //   1. It generates a warning if there is more than one active
00060 //   thread.  This is because it's safe to fork() or clone() only
00061 //   when there is a single thread.
00062 //
00063 //   2. The parent process clone()s a sub-process and runs the death
00064 //   test in it; the sub-process exits with code 0 at the end of the
00065 //   death test, if it hasn't exited already.
00066 //
00067 //   3. The parent process waits for the sub-process to terminate.
00068 //
00069 //   4. The parent process checks the exit code and error message of
00070 //   the sub-process.
00071 //
00072 // Examples:
00073 //
00074 //   ASSERT_DEATH(server.SendMessage(56, "Hello"), "Invalid port number");
00075 //   for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++) {
00076 //     EXPECT_DEATH(server.ProcessRequest(i),
00077 //                  "Invalid request .* in ProcessRequest()")
00078 //         << "Failed to die on request " << i);
00079 //   }
00080 //
00081 //   ASSERT_EXIT(server.ExitNow(), ::testing::ExitedWithCode(0), "Exiting");
00082 //
00083 //   bool KilledBySIGHUP(int exit_code) {
00084 //     return WIFSIGNALED(exit_code) && WTERMSIG(exit_code) == SIGHUP;
00085 //   }
00086 //
00087 //   ASSERT_EXIT(client.HangUpServer(), KilledBySIGHUP, "Hanging up!");
00088 //
00089 // Known caveats:
00090 //
00091 //   A "threadsafe" style death test obtains the path to the test
00092 //   program from argv[0] and re-executes it in the sub-process.  For
00093 //   simplicity, the current implementation doesn't search the PATH
00094 //   when launching the sub-process.  This means that the user must
00095 //   invoke the test program via a path that contains at least one
00096 //   path separator (e.g. path/to/foo_test and
00097 //   /absolute/path/to/bar_test are fine, but foo_test is not).  This
00098 //   is rarely a problem as people usually don't put the test binary
00099 //   directory in PATH.
00100 //
00101 // TODO(wan@google.com): make thread-safe death tests search the PATH.
00102 
00103 // Asserts that a given statement causes the program to exit, with an
00104 // integer exit status that satisfies predicate, and emitting error output
00105 // that matches regex.
00106 #define ASSERT_EXIT(statement, predicate, regex) \
00107   GTEST_DEATH_TEST_(statement, predicate, regex, GTEST_FATAL_FAILURE_)
00108 
00109 // Like ASSERT_EXIT, but continues on to successive tests in the
00110 // test case, if any:
00111 #define EXPECT_EXIT(statement, predicate, regex) \
00112   GTEST_DEATH_TEST_(statement, predicate, regex, GTEST_NONFATAL_FAILURE_)
00113 
00114 // Asserts that a given statement causes the program to exit, either by
00115 // explicitly exiting with a nonzero exit code or being killed by a
00116 // signal, and emitting error output that matches regex.
00117 #define ASSERT_DEATH(statement, regex) \
00118   ASSERT_EXIT(statement, ::testing::internal::ExitedUnsuccessfully, regex)
00119 
00120 // Like ASSERT_DEATH, but continues on to successive tests in the
00121 // test case, if any:
00122 #define EXPECT_DEATH(statement, regex) \
00123   EXPECT_EXIT(statement, ::testing::internal::ExitedUnsuccessfully, regex)
00124 
00125 // Two predicate classes that can be used in {ASSERT,EXPECT}_EXIT*:
00126 
00127 // Tests that an exit code describes a normal exit with a given exit code.
00128 class ExitedWithCode {
00129  public:
00130   explicit ExitedWithCode(int exit_code);
00131   bool operator()(int exit_status) const;
00132  private:
00133   const int exit_code_;
00134 };
00135 
00136 // Tests that an exit code describes an exit due to termination by a
00137 // given signal.
00138 class KilledBySignal {
00139  public:
00140   explicit KilledBySignal(int signum);
00141   bool operator()(int exit_status) const;
00142  private:
00143   const int signum_;
00144 };
00145 
00146 // EXPECT_DEBUG_DEATH asserts that the given statements die in debug mode.
00147 // The death testing framework causes this to have interesting semantics,
00148 // since the sideeffects of the call are only visible in opt mode, and not
00149 // in debug mode.
00150 //
00151 // In practice, this can be used to test functions that utilize the
00152 // LOG(DFATAL) macro using the following style:
00153 //
00154 // int DieInDebugOr12(int* sideeffect) {
00155 //   if (sideeffect) {
00156 //     *sideeffect = 12;
00157 //   }
00158 //   LOG(DFATAL) << "death";
00159 //   return 12;
00160 // }
00161 //
00162 // TEST(TestCase, TestDieOr12WorksInDgbAndOpt) {
00163 //   int sideeffect = 0;
00164 //   // Only asserts in dbg.
00165 //   EXPECT_DEBUG_DEATH(DieInDebugOr12(&sideeffect), "death");
00166 //
00167 // #ifdef NDEBUG
00168 //   // opt-mode has sideeffect visible.
00169 //   EXPECT_EQ(12, sideeffect);
00170 // #else
00171 //   // dbg-mode no visible sideeffect.
00172 //   EXPECT_EQ(0, sideeffect);
00173 // #endif
00174 // }
00175 //
00176 // This will assert that DieInDebugReturn12InOpt() crashes in debug
00177 // mode, usually due to a DCHECK or LOG(DFATAL), but returns the
00178 // appropriate fallback value (12 in this case) in opt mode. If you
00179 // need to test that a function has appropriate side-effects in opt
00180 // mode, include assertions against the side-effects.  A general
00181 // pattern for this is:
00182 //
00183 // EXPECT_DEBUG_DEATH({
00184 //   // Side-effects here will have an effect after this statement in
00185 //   // opt mode, but none in debug mode.
00186 //   EXPECT_EQ(12, DieInDebugOr12(&sideeffect));
00187 // }, "death");
00188 //
00189 #ifdef NDEBUG
00190 
00191 #define EXPECT_DEBUG_DEATH(statement, regex) \
00192   do { statement; } while (false)
00193 
00194 #define ASSERT_DEBUG_DEATH(statement, regex) \
00195   do { statement; } while (false)
00196 
00197 #else
00198 
00199 #define EXPECT_DEBUG_DEATH(statement, regex) \
00200   EXPECT_DEATH(statement, regex)
00201 
00202 #define ASSERT_DEBUG_DEATH(statement, regex) \
00203   ASSERT_DEATH(statement, regex)
00204 
00205 #endif  // NDEBUG for EXPECT_DEBUG_DEATH
00206 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_DEATH_TEST
00207 }  // namespace testing
00208 
00209 #endif  // GTEST_INCLUDE_GTEST_GTEST_DEATH_TEST_H_
